item.title: Teaching as a graduate student
item.description: In this video, I discuss the pros and cons of teaching during graduate school, how to find different types of teaching opportunities, and lessons I have learned from working as an instructor and a teaching assistant. Thanks to Ryan McWay and Carmen Armas Montalvo for organizing the Applied Economics (APEC) Skills Series Workshop and for excellent video production.

item.title: Principles of Economics
item.description: From February to May 2024, I taught Principles of Economics at St. Olaf College to two sections of students. Before this, I worked as a teaching assistant in designing an online version of the course at UMN in the Fall 2022 semester. When I designed the course, I paid special attention to the before-class and after-class assignments to help students establish a consistent rhythm. Before classes, students would read a short article or a news piece related to the subject and briefly answer some reflection questions.

item.title: Barbies Don't Say Sorry
item.description: I enjoyed watching Barbie the movie directed by Greta Gerwig. As I have been following the interviews and discussions around it, I ran into an interview of Margot Robbie, who played as Barbie. In the interview she shared a important lesson that she learned from watching the Barbie’s official YouTube channel. That is, swapping the preventive “sorry” for the word “thank you”. For example, instead of saying “sorry, I can’t do that”, say “thank you for understanding that I couldn’t do that”.

item.title: Graduate level Econometrics
item.description: Econometrics was among the most challenge courses I took in college. Admittedly, terms like “asymptotic” and “parametric” were just too abstract. After taking two versions of this course from different institutions and being the teaching assistant for four instructors that taught this course, I would say that I have climbed up on the spiraling ladder of learning enough to be no longer scared of it. Perhaps the best way to learn it is through viewing the same thing from different angles, and my favorite angle is through Professor Joe Ritter’s data simulation and visualization.

item.title: Math review for new graduate students in applied economics
item.description: This was a 45-hours summer course that I taught remotely in 2020 during the COVID-19 pandemic. It offered new graduate students an opportunity to connect with each other and prepare for the core courses. Some of the students took the course during midnight while they were still restricted in their home country. Every year I am fascinated by how much students are devoted to learn, overcoming barriers of space and time, and even the crazy realities during the pandemic.
